greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of decompositions of 2n+1 into 2p+q, where p and q are both odd primes (A065091).
comment: Conjecture: all items for n>=4 are greater than or equal to 1. This is a stronger conjecture than the Goldbach conjecture.
link: R. J. Mathar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10777
example: For 2*4+1 = 9 we have just one such composition: 9 = 2*3+3, so a(4)=1;
For 2*14+1 = 29 we have four such compositions: 29 = 2*3+23 = 2*5+19 = 2*11+7 = 2*13+3, so a(14)=4.
mathematica: Do[m = 3; ct = 0; While[(m*2) < n, If[PrimeQ[m], cp = n - (2*m); If[ PrimeQ[cp], ct = ct + 1]]; m = m + 2]; Print[ct], {n, 9, 299, 2}]
program: (Scheme, with Aubrey Jaffer's SLIB Scheme library from http://www.swiss.ai.mit.edu/~jaffer/SLIB.html )
(define (A103151 n) (let loop ((i 2) (z 0)) (let ((p1 (A000040 i))) (cond ((>= p1 n) z) ((prime? (+ 1 (* 2 (- n p1)))) (loop (+ 1 i) (+ 1 z))) (else (loop (+ 1 i) z))))))
results.author: _Lei Zhou_, Feb 09 2005
ext: Edited and Scheme-code added by _Antti Karttunen_, Jun 19 2007
